elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">A novel coordination polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> {[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(MDIP)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> has been synthesized using methylenediisophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>MDIP) under hydrothermal conditions. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis indicates that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a 3D porous framework with two types of 1D channel. The structure is further simplified by topology analysis which indicates a (4, 8)-connected net with a Schläfli symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">16</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>) topology. Moreover, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> displays a strong blue photoluminescent property.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract
A novel coordination polymer 1 {[Zn5(MDIP)2(H2O)6(μ3-OH)2]·2H2O}
n
 has been synthesized using methylenediisophthalic acid (H4MDIP) under hydrothermal conditions. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis indicates that 1 shows a 3D porous framework with two types of 1D channel. The structure is further simplified by topology analysis which indicates a (4, 8)-connected net with a Schläfli symbol of (44.62)2(416.612) topology. Moreover, compound 1 displays a strong blue photoluminescent property.

topology.value: (4, 8)-connected net with a Schläfli symbol of (4^4.6^2)_2(4^16.6^12)

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">A novel coordination polymer has been successfully synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis indicates that it shows a 3D porous framework with two types of 1D channel. The structure is further simplified by topology analysis which indicates a (4, 8)-connected net with a Schläfli symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">16</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>) topology. Moreover, this compound displays a strong blue photoluminescent property.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract
A novel coordination polymer has been successfully synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis indicates that it shows a 3D porous framework with two types of 1D channel. The structure is further simplified by topology analysis which indicates a (4, 8)-connected net with a Schläfli symbol of (44.62)2(416.612) topology. Moreover, this compound displays a strong blue photoluminescent property.

elements.content:
<ce:simple-para view="all">
<ce:display>
<ce:figure>
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para><ce:para view="all">During the last few years, self-assembly of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has been well developed, which has grown into a subject that attracts great attention because of their intriguing aesthetic structures and topological features as well as their promising applications as functional materials in areas such as catalysis, optical, electrics, magnetic devices, separation, gas storage and so on . A successful strategy in building such networks is to employ appropriate bridging ligands that can bind metal ions in different modes and provide a possible way to achieve more new materials with beautiful architectures and fascinating potential applications. Organic aromatic polycarboxylate ligands containing multidentate O donors, such as 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate, have been widely used in the construction of metal-organic complexes with high dimensional networks and interesting properties .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: During the last few years, self-assembly of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has been well developed, which has grown into a subject that attracts great attention because of their intriguing aesthetic structures and topological features as well as their promising applications as functional materials in areas such as catalysis, optical, electrics, magnetic devices, separation, gas storage and so on . A successful strategy in building such networks is to employ appropriate bridging ligands that can bind metal ions in different modes and provide a possible way to achieve more new materials with beautiful architectures and fascinating potential applications. Organic aromatic polycarboxylate ligands containing multidentate O donors, such as 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate, have been widely used in the construction of metal-organic complexes with high dimensional networks and interesting properties .

elements.content:
<ce:figure>
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:para view="all">Many polymeric complexes assembled from tertracarboxylate ligands with two phenyl rings have been reported, in which the two phenyl rings were usually connected by oxygen or etheric sulfur atoms . The results showed that such ligands played a vital role in the construction of desired MOFs. In order to understand the coordination chemistry of the similar ligands and prepare new materials with interesting structural topologies and physical properties, we have been focusing in the research of methylenediisophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>MDIP) in which the methylene group acts as a joint connecting two isophthalic acids. H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>MDIP has been employed in our investigation to prepare new materials with new MOFs and advanced application introduced above.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Many polymeric complexes assembled from tertracarboxylate ligands with two phenyl rings have been reported, in which the two phenyl rings were usually connected by oxygen or etheric sulfur atoms . The results showed that such ligands played a vital role in the construction of desired MOFs. In order to understand the coordination chemistry of the similar ligands and prepare new materials with interesting structural topologies and physical properties, we have been focusing in the research of methylenediisophthalic acid (H4MDIP) in which the methylene group acts as a joint connecting two isophthalic acids. H4MDIP has been employed in our investigation to prepare new materials with new MOFs and advanced application introduced above.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">We have reported many novel complexes with different metal ions and methylenediisophthalic acid in our previous work . As a continuous work based on the H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>MDIP ligand, we extend 2D grid and undulated structures ([Zn(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>MDIP)(4,4′-bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (4,4′-bpy<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>4,4′-bipyridine), [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(MDIP)(bix)·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> [bix<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene]) to 3D architectures. A 3D porous architecture with pentanuclear zinc clusters (complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>{[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(MDIP)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>) is formed, which contains two types of 1D channels (marked with A and B). The unique structure not only leads to interesting topological arrangements, but also plays important roles in the complex's photoluminescent activities. Our topological analysis suggests that the complex displays (4, 8)-connected nets. However, pentanuclear polymeric complexes with this kind of structure have seldom been reported. Thermal stabilities are studied using thermogravimetric (TG) analysis. This complex also demonstrates an intensive photoluminescence. In this paper, we report its synthesis, crystal structure, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) and photoluminescence in details.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
We have reported many novel complexes with different metal ions and methylenediisophthalic acid in our previous work . As a continuous work based on the H4MDIP ligand, we extend 2D grid and undulated structures ([Zn(H2MDIP)(4,4′-bpy)0.5]
n
 (4,4′-bpy=4,4′-bipyridine), [Zn2(MDIP)(bix)·H2O]
n
 [bix=1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene]) to 3D architectures. A 3D porous architecture with pentanuclear zinc clusters (complex 1{[Zn5(MDIP)2(H2O)6(μ3-OH)2]·2H2O}
n
) is formed, which contains two types of 1D channels (marked with A and B). The unique structure not only leads to interesting topological arrangements, but also plays important roles in the complex's photoluminescent activities. Our topological analysis suggests that the complex displays (4, 8)-connected nets. However, pentanuclear polymeric complexes with this kind of structure have seldom been reported. Thermal stabilities are studied using thermogravimetric (TG) analysis. This complex also demonstrates an intensive photoluminescence. In this paper, we report its synthesis, crystal structure, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) and photoluminescence in details.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was synthesized hydrothermally with a mixture of Zn(Ac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.0291<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>MDIP (0.0177<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), NaOH (0.08<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and 8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL water sealed in a 15-mL Teflon-lined reactor and heated at 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Complex 1 was synthesized hydrothermally with a mixture of Zn(Ac)2·6H2O (0.0291g, 0.1mmol), H4MDIP (0.0177g, 0.05mmol), NaOH (0.08g, 0.2mmol) and 8mL water sealed in a 15-mL Teflon-lined reactor and heated at 120°C for 3days .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Single-crystal X-ray  diffraction analysis revealed that coordination complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2(1)/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> space group and features a 3D network built from H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>MDIP and Zn(II) atoms (The selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in .). Each crystallographic asymmetrical unit consists of one MDIP ligand, one μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH atom, three zinc atoms, three coordinated water molecules, and three disordered solvent water molecules (the total occupancy for these disordered water molecules is 1). (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>, the solvent O atoms have been omitted here.) As depicted in , the three metal centers display a different coordination environment. Zn<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> atom exhibits a slightly distorted octahedral coordination sphere, which is coordinated by one O atom (O5D) from one bis-mono carboxylate group, one O atom (O9) from one μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH atom, two O atoms (O7E and O8E) from one chelating carboxylate group, and two O atoms from two water molecules (O11 and O12), with O9 and O11 occupying the axial positions (shown in ). While for Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> center, at first glance, it is ligated by one O atom (O9) from one μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH atom, one from one water molecule (O10), and two oxygen atoms (O1 and O3F) from two different carboxylate groups. However, the Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–O8E (2.666<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–O4F (2.513<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) distances suggest nonnegligible interactions between them (see the dotted line in ). Thus Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> center may be regarded as distorted octahedral structure and the surrounding of each Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atom is (4<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2), with the octahedral elongated along the O8E–Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–O10 axis (see  and the symmetry codes are listed in the ). O8E acts as μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-O to link Zn<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> and Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> adopts an octahedral geometry which is coordinated by four O atoms (O2, O2G, O6D, and O6H) from four bis-mono carboxylate groups and two μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH atoms (O9 and O9G), with the octahedral elongated along the O2–Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>–O2G axis. O9 acts as μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH to link Zn<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>, Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> to form a triangle unit. The average Zn⋯Zn distance is 3.472<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Zn–O bond lengths range over 1.961(3)–2.443(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Å, which is in the normal range . The dihedral angles between two phenyl rings of MDIP are 72.156(1)°, and the angle around the C atom in methylene of MDIP ligand is 111.192(3)°.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Single-crystal X-ray  diffraction analysis revealed that coordination complex 1 crystallizes in the P2(1)/n space group and features a 3D network built from H4MDIP and Zn(II) atoms (The selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in .). Each crystallographic asymmetrical unit consists of one MDIP ligand, one μ3-OH atom, three zinc atoms, three coordinated water molecules, and three disordered solvent water molecules (the total occupancy for these disordered water molecules is 1). (
, the solvent O atoms have been omitted here.) As depicted in , the three metal centers display a different coordination environment. Zn1 atom exhibits a slightly distorted octahedral coordination sphere, which is coordinated by one O atom (O5D) from one bis-mono carboxylate group, one O atom (O9) from one μ3-OH atom, two O atoms (O7E and O8E) from one chelating carboxylate group, and two O atoms from two water molecules (O11 and O12), with O9 and O11 occupying the axial positions (shown in ). While for Zn2 center, at first glance, it is ligated by one O atom (O9) from one μ3-OH atom, one from one water molecule (O10), and two oxygen atoms (O1 and O3F) from two different carboxylate groups. However, the Zn2–O8E (2.666Å) and Zn2–O4F (2.513Å) distances suggest nonnegligible interactions between them (see the dotted line in ). Thus Zn2 center may be regarded as distorted octahedral structure and the surrounding of each Zn2 atom is (4+2), with the octahedral elongated along the O8E–Zn2–O10 axis (see  and the symmetry codes are listed in the ). O8E acts as μ2-O to link Zn1 and Zn2. Zn3 adopts an octahedral geometry which is coordinated by four O atoms (O2, O2G, O6D, and O6H) from four bis-mono carboxylate groups and two μ3-OH atoms (O9 and O9G), with the octahedral elongated along the O2–Zn3–O2G axis. O9 acts as μ3-OH to link Zn1, Zn2 and Zn3 to form a triangle unit. The average Zn⋯Zn distance is 3.472Å, and the Zn–O bond lengths range over 1.961(3)–2.443(3)Å, which is in the normal range . The dihedral angles between two phenyl rings of MDIP are 72.156(1)°, and the angle around the C atom in methylene of MDIP ligand is 111.192(3)°.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> also confirmed a novel pentanuclear unit Zn<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> cluster (Zn<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>–Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–O9–Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>–O9G–Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>G–Zn<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>G) (), which is formed through two μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH atoms (O9 and O9G) and four bridging carboxylate groups from four different MDIP ligands. As shown in , each MDIP ligand links four pentanuclear metal clusters, the two adjacent pentanuclear units are connected together by isophthalic acids of MDIP ligands along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> direction. The whole three-dimensional porous framework can then be achieved through the extension of MDIP methylene groups in the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> direction, as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>. Seen from the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis, the structure of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> consists of two types of 1D porous channel which are arranged alternately with <ce:italic>ABAB</ce:italic> model. The disordered free water molecules (O13, O14 and O15, with the occupancy of 0.6 for O13, and 0.3 for both O14 and O15 atoms) fill in the space of host framework. In addition, within the 3D network, there are nanosized cavities with 6.92<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>6.22<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> in channel A and channel B with approximate dimensions of 7.47<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>6.91<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>. A representation of the open framework is displayed in right of the .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structure of 1 also confirmed a novel pentanuclear unit Zn5(μ3-OH)2 cluster (Zn1–Zn2–O9–Zn3–O9G–Zn2G–Zn1G) (), which is formed through two μ3-OH atoms (O9 and O9G) and four bridging carboxylate groups from four different MDIP ligands. As shown in , each MDIP ligand links four pentanuclear metal clusters, the two adjacent pentanuclear units are connected together by isophthalic acids of MDIP ligands along the a direction. The whole three-dimensional porous framework can then be achieved through the extension of MDIP methylene groups in the c direction, as shown in 
. Seen from the b axis, the structure of complex 1 consists of two types of 1D porous channel which are arranged alternately with ABAB model. The disordered free water molecules (O13, O14 and O15, with the occupancy of 0.6 for O13, and 0.3 for both O14 and O15 atoms) fill in the space of host framework. In addition, within the 3D network, there are nanosized cavities with 6.92×6.22Å2 in channel A and channel B with approximate dimensions of 7.47×6.91Å2. A representation of the open framework is displayed in right of the .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>, each pentanuclear unit is surrounded by eight different MDIP ligands to form an eight-connected node exhibiting distorted parallelepiped geometry (see ). After removing the oxygen atoms of the coordinated water molecules and hydroxide ions, a clearer coordination environment of the pentanuclear unit by the eight MDIP ligands can be seen in the middle of a. The building block of the pentanuclear unit is shown in right of a. Each pentanuclear unit in the <ce:italic>bc</ce:italic> plane is bridged by MDIP ligands to generate an extended 3D brick wall like porous network as shown in b. The bridging MDIP ligands are arranged alternately along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> direction in two ways, with C5–C7–C8 angle of MDIP ligand bend down and bend up respectively (). The chair-like dodecagon cavity is composed by four pentanuclear units and four MDIP ligands. The whole brick wall like porous framework is then constructed through the alternate arrangement of these dodecagon chair-like cavities (as shown in b). The disordered water (O13 and O14) molecules are encapsulated in the dodecagon porous framework (). Worth to be mentioned is that there are face to face <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> interactions between two MDIP rings (the distance between two adjacent phenyl rings is 3.53<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) in the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> direction with the dihedral angle of 15.1° (see ). When omitting the guest lattice water, a calculation using PLATON  suite of programs led to a potential solvent area of 298.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, namely 14.1% of the total crystal volume. Worth to be mentioned is that the porous channels found in this framework are not stable when heated. It may be ascribed to the six coordinated water molecules and the coordinated oxygen atoms from two hydroxyl groups, and it also might be the case of the weak <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> interactions constructing the 3D framework. Topological approach has been performed to analyze and understand more clearly the complicated structure of the framework. If we define the pentanuclear metal cluster as an 8-connected node, and MDIP ligand as a 4-connected node, the framework can be described as an unusual (4, 8)-connected network  (shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>) with a Schläfli symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">16</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>) topology which is an scu net  (see ).</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">Taking into account the excellent luminescent properties of d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> metal complexes, the solid-state emission spectra of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> have been investigated at room temperature as described in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>. The complex exhibits an intense emission peak at ca. 434<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm upon excitation at ca. 341<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. Moreover, a shoulder peak at 526<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm was found in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, which is corresponding to the shoulder peak at 520<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm in H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>MDIP ligand . Since Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions is difficult to oxidize or to reduce due to its d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> configuration, the emission peak located in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) in nature, may be assigned to the intraligand (<ce:italic>π</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>π</ce:italic>*) transitions of the ligand H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>MDIP as free H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>MDIP shows approximate emissions . The obvious shift relative to that of the free ligand (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">max</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>350 and 495<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm), may be attributed to the ligation of MDIP ligand to the metal center, which effectively increases the rigidity and reduces the loss of energy by radiationless decay . These observations indicate that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> may be suitable as a potential candidate of blue-fluorescent materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Taking into account the excellent luminescent properties of d10 metal complexes, the solid-state emission spectra of complex 1 have been investigated at room temperature as described in 
. The complex exhibits an intense emission peak at ca. 434nm upon excitation at ca. 341nm. Moreover, a shoulder peak at 526nm was found in complex 1, which is corresponding to the shoulder peak at 520nm in H4MDIP ligand . Since Zn2+ ions is difficult to oxidize or to reduce due to its d10 configuration, the emission peak located in 1, neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) in nature, may be assigned to the intraligand (π–π*) transitions of the ligand H4MDIP as free H4MDIP shows approximate emissions . The obvious shift relative to that of the free ligand (λ
max
=350 and 495nm), may be attributed to the ligation of MDIP ligand to the metal center, which effectively increases the rigidity and reduces the loss of energy by radiationless decay . These observations indicate that 1 may be suitable as a potential candidate of blue-fluorescent materials.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were conducted to explore the compositional stability of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, which is an important parameter for MOF materials. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor>, the TGA curve for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> indicates two weight-loss stages: the first weight loss starting from 60 to 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to lose guest and coordinated water molecules, followed by a stage until 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The weight loss of 15.24% below 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (calcd. 15.02%) corresponds to the loss of free water molecules and coordinated water molecules per formula. The framework started to decompose above 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Complete decomposition of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was finished at above 520<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which is consistent with the removal of organic ligands. To further verify whether the framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be sustained after the absence of the guest molecules, sample <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was heated at 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h in air to remove the solvent molecules. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis indicates that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> does not maintain its structure after losing the guest water molecules (see ).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were conducted to explore the compositional stability of 1, which is an important parameter for MOF materials. As shown in 
, the TGA curve for 1 indicates two weight-loss stages: the first weight loss starting from 60 to 120°C to lose guest and coordinated water molecules, followed by a stage until 400°C. The weight loss of 15.24% below 120°C (calcd. 15.02%) corresponds to the loss of free water molecules and coordinated water molecules per formula. The framework started to decompose above 400°C. Complete decomposition of 1 was finished at above 520°C, which is consistent with the removal of organic ligands. To further verify whether the framework of 1 can be sustained after the absence of the guest molecules, sample 1 was heated at 150°C for 2h in air to remove the solvent molecules. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis indicates that complex 1 does not maintain its structure after losing the guest water molecules (see ).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In summary, we have successfully produced a 3D porous framework with pentanuclear zinc clusters constructed from H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>DMIP, which consists of two kinds of 1D channels arranged alternately with <ce:italic>ABAB</ce:italic> motif along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis. Moreover, a 3D brick wall like porous network with chair-like dodecagon cavities is shaped in the <ce:italic>bc</ce:italic> plane. The complex contains μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH atoms that bridge the three metal ions together to form triangle units. A novel (4, 8) net, with (4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">16</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>) topological structure has been found in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. In addition, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> displays a strong photoluminescent property in solid state, which makes it an excellent candidate of potential blue-fluorescent materials. We are exploring this interesting system with other metal ions for the development of other applications, and further efforts on this perspective are ongoing in our lab.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have successfully produced a 3D porous framework with pentanuclear zinc clusters constructed from H4DMIP, which consists of two kinds of 1D channels arranged alternately with ABAB motif along the b axis. Moreover, a 3D brick wall like porous network with chair-like dodecagon cavities is shaped in the bc plane. The complex contains μ3-OH atoms that bridge the three metal ions together to form triangle units. A novel (4, 8) net, with (44.62)2(416.612) topological structure has been found in 1. In addition, compound 1 displays a strong photoluminescent property in solid state, which makes it an excellent candidate of potential blue-fluorescent materials. We are exploring this interesting system with other metal ions for the development of other applications, and further efforts on this perspective are ongoing in our lab.

metadata.title: A novel 3D (4, 8)-connected metal-organic framework of scu topology with two types of 1D channel constructed by methylenediisophthalic acid (H4MDIP)
